title: Saint Laura
text:
Saint Laura of Cordoba (; died 864) was a <a href="Spanish%20people">Spanish</a> <a href="Christianity">Christian</a> who lived in <a href="Muslim%20Spain">Muslim Spain</a> during the 9th century. She was born in <a href="C%C3%B3rdoba%2C%20Spain">Córdoba</a>, and became a nun at <a href="Cuteclara">Cuteclara</a> after her husband died, eventually rising to become an <a href="abbess">abbess</a>. She was martyred by Muslims, who took her captive and scalded her to death by placing her in a vat of boiling pitch. Her feast day is on 19 October; she is one of the <a href="Martyrs%20of%20C%C3%B3rdoba">Martyrs of Córdoba</a>.
She is commemorated by the <a href="Estadio%20Santa%20Laura">Estadio Santa Laura</a> ("Saint Laura Stadium") in <a href="Santiago">Santiago</a>, Chile and the <a href="Humberstone%20and%20Santa%20Laura%20Saltpeter%20Works">Humberstone and Santa Laura Saltpeter Works</a> in northern Chile.
<a href="Thomas%20Love%20Peacock">Thomas Love Peacock</a> wrote a ballad about Saint Laura in his work <a href="Gryll%20Grange">Gryll Grange</a>.
